data: Initially adopted in Kyoto towards the end of 1997, the Kyoto Protocol, which aims to combat global warming by cutting greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, is arguably the most important international environment treatys.
Thirty-seven key countries have made a specific commitment to cut emissions of four GHGs.
There has been much debate about such emissions targets, in particular how achievable and costly they are.
Emissions trading, the clean development mechanism and joint implementation offer flexible mechanisms for countries to meet Kyoto targets by purchasing credits for GHG reduction.

However, the underlying question of Kyoto’s relevance rests on whether or not one considers the causes of global warming to be man-made or due to natural causes, such as the cycle of glacial and inter-glacial periods.

Whilst there has certainly been a recent spike in global warming and human activity must have played at least some part in causing this, some people believe that the Kyoto Protocol is based on a false assumption that only humans are to blame for causing global warming.
Agnosticism describes the position of abstaining from the question of whether or not a deity exists.
This contrasts with atheism’s lack of belief in any god, a position that is usually based on the lack of any scientific evidence for the existence of a god.
Whilst this philosophy is invariably equated with irreligion, there are in fact certain religions, such as forms of Buddhism, which do not encompass belief in a particular god.
Whilst an atheist is unlikely to adhere to a single ideology, common preferences are often found for humanism, naturalism or other secular philosophies.
Throughout history, atheists have laid important philosophical foundations initially from the use of the term as an accusatory label to describe those who attacked established orthodoxy.
This can be traced in the historical record through from the trials of Socrates right up to the 1963 Supreme Court’s school prayer decision, which actually defended the civil rights of atheists.
The burden of a country’s external debt becomes what is called “unpayable debt” when the level of interest exceeds the amount that a government can extract in taxes from its population.
There were many causes of unpayable debt in developing countries, including the legacy of colonialism, and some of these causes are quite difficult to justify now.

The historical roots of mounting developing world debt stretch back to mismanaged Western lending throughout the 1970’s – particularly for projects with low viability – and then the subsequent interest rate rises on the loans in the 1980’s.
The 1973 Oil Crisis had a specific impact for many of those developing countries who borrowed heavily to buy crucial supplies.

At the same time, oil profits - banked in the West - needed to be re-invested, and there was a need for recently independent developing countries to obtain loans in order to pay for large infrastructure projects.
Specific DNA sequences can be isolated and/or modified – the gene sequencing process – which then allows gene patents to be taken out.
A significant part of the biological patenting industry is represented by medical and agricultural companies.
Such patents grant the proprietary rights on unique segments of DNA code for a particular disease.
Some cancer gene patents have recently been overturned by the American courts and this has brought many controversial issues to the fore.
There has been some legal uncertainty over exactly what is covered by a gene patent.
Under United States law it is controversially the DNA sequence, as well as the processes involved that are patented.
The rationale for issuing such patents on the basis of incentivising further research has proved particularly controversial.
The principle of patenting is not inherently wrong or uneconomical.
However, is it morally right to apply patent law in such a way as to patent nature itself?
Global communications pose an increasing threat to minority languages, such as the use of the Welsh language within the UK and the use of the French language across Canada.
Micro-languages, such as those spoken by some Amazonian tribes, are also threatened alongside other village traditions.

Language’s overall purpose is effective communication, but in practice the life of a language must depend upon the number of people who can continue to use that language as a means of communicating with each other.
The decline of a minority language not only reduces a region’s language diversity, but also dilutes its whole cultural heritage.
This is particularly true of the Aboriginal language since the history of the Aborigines is entirely dependent upon the preservation of oral storytelling traditions.
Likewise, the Roma’s cultural identity relies strongly upon the Romany language, as the Romany people do not possess a homeland.

Should scarce financial resources be prioritised towards preserving a threatened language? Without state intervention it’s difficult to see how the thousands of speakers that are needed to keep a threatened language alive can be sustained.

In July 2002 in The Hague, the International Criminal Court (ICC), began operating as a court of last resort, prosecuting crimes against humanity and war crimes when national courts have not been able or have been unwilling to act.
Today’s Court has extended its reach to 111 member states.

In addition to acting when an alleged crime has occurred within a member state’s territory, the ICC has jurisdiction to act under two other conditions: from a United Nations Security Council referral, or when the accused party belongs to a member state.

The U.S., Indonesia, India and China were not among the requisite 60 countries that ratified the Rome Statute and established the permanent tribunal, although in 2008 Barack Obama suggested that the U.S. may join.

Whilst the US has supported international trials for war criminals, some believe that by joining the ICC the US may increase the likelihood of its own citizens being targeted – given America’s prominent role in world events – rather than such citizens being prosecuted by America’s own legal system.
Another reason for not consenting to the jurisdiction of the ICC has been the need to improve safeguards against politically motivated prosecutions.
One of the advantages of joining would be US participation in any necessary reforms of the ICC.
Biofuels, which are less polluting than fossil fuels, represent one potential solution to reversing global climate change and reducing reliance on the world’s dwindling supplies of oil.
In theory, any biological carbon source can be used in biofuel production.
One such source, agricultural crops, also represents a renewable energy source.
Some examples of first generation biofuels – those made using conventional technology – are bioethanols and biodiesel, which are commonly used as vehicle fuel.
Bioethanols are the most common biofuels worldwide and are made from starch crops and sugar.
Biodiesel is made from vegetable oils or animal fats.
Second and third generation biofuels are made from non-food crops and algae plants respectively.
Some scientists believe that the economies of scale from increasing production of the latter could prove sufficiently economical to replace oil as an energy source.
However, such biofuel production requires large areas of open-land in order to harness the solar energy that is then stored in the plant’s biomass.
Non-Marxist forms of communism have grown in importance since the fall of the Soviet Union.
The branch of socialism called communism now covers a plethora of political and social ideologies.
Karl Marx’s original work offered an alternative to the problems of the world’s capitalist economic systems and imperialism’s legacies.
A communist system based on Marxist principles was applied in the Soviet Union, although establishing a stateless society has its own problems.
Firstly, common ownership of the means of production is difficult to attain without having someone (or some government body) deciding who has access.
In effect someone must act as the owner of the aforementioned means of production.

Secondly, whichever way “collective ownership of property” is defined by the Marxist approach, it still entails control over said property by the government, thus diminishing an individual’s inviolable rights.
Thirdly, the Communist principle of each citizen being equal does not apply to the leadership roles within a Communist state.
Under the Kyoto Protocol countries must act independently to reduce GHG emissions.
False – this can be inferred from the passage.
It is erroneous to believe that global warming is a man-made problem.
Cannot Say – the passage does not state this, neither does it contradict this statement.
Over thirty countries have agreed to the Kyoto Protocol.
True – the passage refers to “37 key countries”.
The Kyoto Protocol is an essential symbol in the fight against global warming.
Cannot Say – the passage states that it is “arguably the most important international environment treaties”, but does not refer to the Protocol as an essential symbol.
The Kyoto Protocol aims to reduce all greenhouse gas emissions.
False - The Kyoto Protocol aims to reduce the emissions for four greenhouse gases.
An agnostic denies the existence of any deity.
False – this position describes atheism.
Atheism is rooted in a range of philosophical systems.
True – paraphrases the forth sentence.
The passage suggests that Buddhism is not a religion.
False – the passage highlights that there are “certain religions, such as forms of Buddhism, which do not encompass belief in a particular god”.
There is a lack of evidence for the existence of any god.
True – the second sentence of the passage states that there is a “lack of any scientific evidence for the existence of a god”.
Atheism can be a pejorative term.
True – the passage refers to the “accusatory labelling of those who attacked established orthodoxy”.
The burden of debt in some developing countries is unfair.
True – this can be inferred from the third sentence.
Some of the loan investments made to developing countries in 1973 were ill-advised.
True – this can be inferred from the fourth sentence.
“Unpayable debt” refers to a country’s willingness to repay its external debt.
False – the term refers to “when the level of interest exceeds the amount that a government can extract in taxes from its population.”
One of the legacies of colonialism was the need to pay for large infrastructure projects.
Cannot Say – the passage refers to the debts left by colonialism, as well as the large infrastructure projects of recently independent developing countries.
Oil profits were partly used to fund large infrastructure projects in developing countries.
True – this can be inferred from the last sentence. Oil profits of the developed world were reinvested in the West as loans to bankroll the large infrastructure projects of developing countries.
There is a lack of consensus about whether issuing gene patents restricts further research.
True – the “rationale for issuing such patents on the basis of incentivising further research has proved particularly controversial”.
It is standard practice for a gene patent to cover the DNA sequence detection process.

Cannot Say – the passage states that “under US law it is both the DNA sequence and the processes involved that are patented”, but no information is given about whether or not this is standard practice.
The issuing of patents is a lucrative but morally objectionable practice.
False – the passage is concerned with gene patenting rather than patenting in general, and furthermore states that the “principle of patenting is not... uneconomical.”
Once granted, patented ownership rights cannot be revoked.
False – the passage mentions that “recently some cancer gene patents have been overturned by the American courts”.
The biological patenting industry has caused both ethical and legal controversy.
True – the passage refers to the legal confusion caused and also questions whether they are morally right.
Governments have a responsibility to preserve a region’s cultural heritage, including any minority languages.
Cannot Say – the passage raises points for and against the allocation of “scarce financial resources”.
Language is the key factor in a region’s cultural identity.
Cannot say – the passage states that “the decline of a minority language. . . dilutes its whole cultural heritage” but it does not follow that it is the key factor.
Preserving micro-languages is a way of reversing the spread of global communications.
False – it is the “increasing threat to minority languages” posed by global communications that the passage refers to.
Welsh and French Canadian village traditions are in decline due to the influence of mass communications.
Cannot say – while the first sentence refers to these regions, and the second sentence refers to threatened village traditions in the Amazon, it does not necessarily follow that these are linked.
There is a strong emphasis on oral communication in Aboriginal culture.
True – “the history of the Aborigines is entirely dependent upon the preservation of storytelling traditions”.
The ICC began operating in 2002 across 111 member states.
False – the ICC was set-up in 2002, however it can be inferred from the following sentence; “Today’s Court has extended its reach to 111 member states” that initially there were less member states.
The ICC was set-up to complement national judicial systems.
True – the ICC is a complementary judicial system for “when national courts have not been able or have been unwilling to act”.
Sixty countries needed to sign the Rome Statue to put it into effect.
True – the passage states that this was the requisite number.
The U.S. does not support the ICC’s approach to prosecuting war criminals.
Cannot Say – the second half of the passage debates this issue.
There is a danger of the ICC being accused of being politically motivated.
True – this is a logical inference from the penultimate sentence.
Biofuels can only be produced from food crops.
False – “any biological carbon source can be used in biofuel production”.
First and second generation biofuels are so-called because each comes from a biological carbon source.
Cannot Say – the passage does not explain why first and second generation biofuels are so-called.
Worldwide biofuel production capacity is growing.
Cannot Say – the passage does not refer to this.
More efficient biofuel production is needed to create a viable oil substitute.
Cannot Say – the passage states that some scientists believe that a more efficient production of algae biofuel could produce an oil substitute.
Expanding biofuel production has agricultural, social and economic implications.
Cannot Say – the passage mentions agricultural and economic implications from expanding biofuel production – but not social implications.
Marxism was discredited by the fall of the Soviet Union.
Cannot Say – the passage does not state whether or not Marxism was “discredited” by the fall of the Soviet Union.
Communism and socialism are mutually exclusive.
False – communism is a branch of socialism.
A broad range of political philosophies encompass communist principles.
True – based upon the second sentence.
A Communist leader has more power than the average citizen.
True – this can be inferred from the statement that “The Communist principle of each citizen being equal does not apply to the leadership roles within a Communist state”.
The passage questions some Marxist principles.
True – “whichever way “collective ownership of property” is defined by the Marxist approach”.
